conclusion: If the light is moved while its height above the floor remains the same, the only two things that change are the direction of the shadows and their foreshortening/stretching.
When the light is moved to the back-left of the scene, all shadows swing to the viewer’s side of the objects and slightly to the right.
The shadow of A (glove) now appears in front-right of the glove.
The shadow of B (ring) slides to the front-right of the ring, still small and roughly oval.
The shadow of C (notice board) becomes a large rectangle in front-right of the board.
The shadow of D (postcard + cylinder) slides to the front-right of the cylinder; the postcard’s rectangular patch sits on the right-hand edge of the cylinder’s shadow.

Because the light is still at the same height but now behind the objects, the horizontal distance between light and the objects is longer, so every shadow is a little longer than it is now (they are stretched away from the light).
When the light is moved to the back-right of the scene, all shadows swing to the viewer’s side and to the left.
The shadow of A moves to the front-left of the glove.
The shadow of B moves to the front-left of the ring.
The shadow of C moves to the front-left of the notice board.
The shadow of D moves to the front-left of the cylinder and postcard.
As in case 1, all four shadows lengthen for the same reason (greater horizontal distance to the light).
Shape distortions are exactly the mirror image of those in case 1.
Summary: Back-left light = shadows front-right and longer. Back-right light = shadows front-left and longer.
